text: Executive Summary
label: H1

text: Since November 2020, the OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data (the Centre) has been investigating the
label: BODY

text: usability and insight of COVID-19 funding data made available through the International Aid
label: BODY

text: Transparency Initiative (IATI) standard. Our experience has given us a strong appreciation of the value
label: BODY

text: of the IATI standard and its community of publishers. We have also seen where IATI falls short by
label: BODY

text: making data use unnecessarily difficult and time consuming, and missing opportunities to make
label: BODY

text: international aid data more transparent.
label: BODY

text: Over the course of this project, the Centre conducted research with IATI stakeholders and publishers to
label: BODY

text: better understand their needs and capabilities. We developed and documented algorithms to
label: BODY

text: deduplicate and aggregate IATI data into meaningful figures. We produced an IATI COVID-19 Funding
label: BODY

text: Dashboard for users to visualize, explore and analyze all of the published IATI data that is related to the
label: BODY

text: pandemic. And we created a data story to share key insights about COVID-19 commitments and
label: BODY

text: spending.
label: BODY

text: In our engagement with IATI publishers, we found that they were mainly focused on their own data
label: BODY

text: and whether it was accurate. The dashboard allowed publishers to see their data visualized, often for
label: BODY

text: the first time, making data issues immediately apparent. We know of several publishers that made
label: BODY

text: changes to their IATI data after using the dashboard, creating a positive feedback loop.
label: BODY

text: At the same time, our behind-the-scenes technical work to aggregate IATI data revealed a host of
label: BODY

text: issues with data quality. We faced significant challenges evaluating whether data was loosely or strictly
label: BODY

text: related to COVID-19. In attempting to use algorithmic processes to combine IATI data, we then had to
label: BODY

text: spend time considering how confident we were with the outcomes.
label: BODY

text: We believe that the international aid community has just begun to tap the potential of IATI as a
label: BODY

text: data source but that improvements are needed to the IATI standard, guidance and governance in
label: BODY

text: order to reach the goal of aid transparency.
label: BODY

text: We have identified four high-level issues from using IATI COVID-19 data:
label: BODY

text: Barriers to data use: Those who use IATI data, as we attempted to, will always try to do so
label: BODY

text: across a range of publishers. There is too much complexity and too many inconsistencies in
label: BODY

text: IATI publishing for this to scale.
label: BODY

text: No feedback loops: IATI data users are left to resolve familiar problems time and again, with
label: BODY

text: little chance to engage with publishers. The process for improving the IATI standard is unclear
label: BODY

text: and slow.
label: BODY

text: Individual focus: IATI publishers focus on their own data which is then expressed in different
label: BODY

text: approaches and uses of the IATI standard. There is little dialogue between and among
label: BODY

text: organizations to use and improve each other's data. Pockets of collaboration do exist, but have
label: BODY

text: been overshadowed by IATI being centered on compliance.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data | Join our mailing list | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Page 2 of 17
label: BODY

text: The IATI standard is both too rigid and too flexible: All IATI publishers have to put their data
label: BODY

text: into an activity which may not translate to the reality of their operations. In working with the
label: BODY

text: IATI data, we had to bypass activities to get to the financial flows. At the same time, it is often
label: BODY

text: not possible to trace funding between organizations because publishers don’t identify
label: BODY

text: counterparties.
label: BODY

text: We recommend three high-level actions to improve IATI:
label: BODY

text: The governance of IATI needs to be more open to feedback from data users. The IATI
label: BODY

text: Institutional Review, which is currently taking place, should consider ideas around user-led
label: BODY

text: governance and feedback.
label: BODY

text: IATI guidance should be updated more often and include examples of best practice and good
label: BODY

text: use rather than just instructions or definitions.
label: BODY

text: Rankings and indices for IATI publishers should include performance metrics on collective
label: BODY

text: and systematic data use in addition to focusing on the data quality of individual publishers.
label: BODY

text: Many of our findings and recommendations are already covered in the IATI Strategic Plan 2020 - 2025
label: BODY

text: including a focus on data quality and data use. This report includes a detailed list of recommendations
label: BODY

text: and suggested next steps (see Section 3). For each issue, we propose what changes would be most
label: BODY

text: beneficial, and equally importantly, how the IATI community might implement them.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data | Join our mailing list | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Page 3 of 17
label: BODY

text: 1. Introduction
label: HH1

text: The International Aid Transparency Initiative is a global effort to improve the transparency of
label: BODY

text: development and humanitarian financing focused on addressing poverty and humanitarian crises.
label: BODY

text: More than 1,300 organizations — bilateral and multilateral providers, international and local NGOs,
label: BODY

text: civil society organizations, academia, governments, and other stakeholders — publish their data using
label: BODY

text: the IATI standard.
label: BODY

text: Following the World Health Organization’s declaration of a pandemic in March 2020, the IATI
label: BODY

text: secretariat issued guidance on how to publish data on COVID-19 aid activities and financial
label: BODY

text: transactions. Organizations were encouraged to add ‘COVID-19’ in additional fields of the IATI standard
label: BODY

text: in order to track the response to the pandemic. As of September 2021, over 200 organizations have
label: BODY

text: published their COVID-19 funding data using IATI.
label: BODY

text: Over the past nine months, the Centre has explored this data to understand the financial
label: BODY

text: commitments and actual spending related to the pandemic. As part of this project, we developed an
label: BODY

text: IATI COVID-19 Funding Dashboard (updated nightly) with financial transactions from 13,780 reported
label: BODY

text: aid activities covering $134.5 billion in commitments and $84.8 billion in spending directed towards
label: BODY

text: 200 recipient countries and territories.1 We also created a data story which shows several insights from
label: BODY

text: the data (as of 15 September).
label: BODY

text: This report details our experience using the IATI COVID-19 data to create the dashboard and related
label: BODY

text: data story. We explain our goals with the dashboard and the methodology we used to parse and
label: BODY

text: visualize the IATI data. The report concludes with a deeper look at the issues we encountered and
label: BODY

text: offers recommendations for improving the IATI standard and related guidance.
label: BODY

text: The work covered in this project was funded by the United States Agency for International
label: BODY

text: Development (USAID). We are grateful for the considerable contribution of USAID colleagues in
label: BODY

text: reviewing and providing feedback on our work. We would also like to acknowledge the earlier effort to
label: BODY

text: create a prototype visualization to track the COVID-19 response by Development Initiatives which was
label: BODY

text: undertaken on behalf of the Grand Bargain Transparency Workstream.2
label: BODY

text: 2. The IATI COVID-19 Funding Dashboard
label: H1

text: The dashboard was created to visualize, explore and analyze all of the published IATI data related to
label: BODY

text: the COVID-19 pandemic. We focused on two main entities in IATI reports: 1) the activity, which may
label: BODY

text: represent any unit of aid action (such as a programme, project, or activity); and 2) the transaction,
label: BODY

text: which represents a single movement of money (or promise) in or out of the activity (such as a payment
label: BODY

text: 2 A snapshot of the earlier dashboard, developed by Mark Brough at Development Initiatives, is available at
label: BODY

text: https://covid19.humportal.org/activities/ .
label: BODY

text: 1 All figures according to the dashboard as of 30 September 2021. These figures are updated nightly so will
label: BODY

text: change.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data | Join our mailing list | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Page 4 of 17
label: BODY

text: to an implementing partner, or a grant from a donor). (Read more about IATI transaction types in
label: BODY

text: Annex A).
label: BODY

text: A guiding principle for developing the dashboard has been to ‘hold up a mirror’ to IATI data. Therefore,
label: BODY

text: the dashboard presents financial information as reported, without attempting any reconciliation
label: BODY

text: among different publishing organizations or verification of those numbers from other sources.
label: BODY

text: The dashboard has three target audiences:
label: BODY

text: IATI data publishers: people involved in the production and distribution of data formatted to
label: BODY

text: the IATI standard.
label: BODY

text: IATI data users: people interested in IATI data more widely, either from an analytical or
label: BODY

text: transparency perspective.
label: BODY

text: COVID-19 funding observers: people interested in the response to the pandemic, but not
label: BODY

text: necessarily in IATI itself.
label: BODY

text: We designed the dashboard to be open source and reusable, so that — with a certain amount of
label: BODY

text: reconfiguration — it can be deployed to track other topics or crises using the IATI standard. (Read more
label: BODY

text: about the algorithms and general methodology we used to process IATI data and find links to our
label: BODY

text: GitHub repositories in Annex B).
label: BODY

text: The dashboard includes four tabs:
label: BODY

text: Commitments and Spending — visualization of money committed and actually spent overall,
label: BODY

text: or filtered by organization, sector, or country.
label: BODY

text: Spending Flows — visualization of incoming and outgoing financial flows overall, or by
label: BODY

text: organization.
label: BODY

text: Data Story — a link out to funding insights using COVID-19 IATI data.
label: BODY

text: About This Dashboard — detailed information about the dashboard, including sources,
label: BODY

text: methodology, and licensing.
label: BODY

text: The dashboard allows users to pose questions about COVID-19 aid funding and discover IATI data to
label: BODY

text: help answer them, such as: how much money have aid organizations committed to the COVID-19
label: BODY

text: response in Haiti?; what sector received the most COVID-19 funding?; or which organizations received
label: BODY

text: funding from the African Development Bank? It is also possible to see only humanitarian-flagged
label: BODY

text: funding, or to apply strict or loose rules for COVID-19 relevance.
label: BODY

text: Despite our best efforts and significant user consultation, use of the dashboard requires some degree
label: BODY

text: of domain expertise to explore and understand the data. (See Annex C for more about our stakeholder
label: BODY

text: consultations). To reach a broader audience, we produced a data story that provides a curated view of
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data | Join our mailing list | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Page 5 of 17
label: BODY

text: the major insights from the COVID-19 data over a fixed period from January to September 2021,
label: BODY

text: including:
label: BODY

text: How quickly IATI publishers began sharing COVID-19-related data.
label: BODY

text: How organization type (e.g. NGO, multilateral, government) is correlated with the frequency of
label: BODY

text: IATI publishing.
label: BODY

text: The uneven distribution of gaps between money committed and money actually spent for
label: BODY

text: different countries.
label: BODY

text: The major aid sectors targeted with COVID-19-related funding.
label: BODY

text: The distribution of funding for the health sector over time.
label: BODY

text: Gaps in IATI data around organization-to-organization money flows.
label: BODY

text: Unlike the dashboard, which updates nightly, the data story is based on a snapshot of data from 15
label: BODY

text: September 2021 and will not be updated. However, up-to-date versions of all the data are available for
label: BODY

text: download on the Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX) in the dataset IATI COVID-19-related funding
label: BODY

text: data.
label: BODY

text: 3. Key Findings and Recommendations
label: H1

text: During the course of this project, the Centre has become a significant IATI data user, and we have
label: BODY

text: involved many members of our team who had previously had no exposure to the standard. Our
label: BODY

text: experience has given us a strong appreciation of the value of the IATI standard and its community of
label: BODY

text: publishers. We believe that the international aid community has just begun to tap the potential of IATI
label: BODY

text: as a data source.
label: BODY

text: We have also had the opportunity to see where the IATI standard, guidance, and community practices
label: BODY

text: fall short, making data use unnecessarily difficult, and missing opportunities to provide the
label: BODY

text: information that could make international aid more transparent.
label: BODY

text: We have identified five issues related to the IATI standard and guidance. For each of these findings, we
label: BODY

text: propose what changes would be most beneficial and how the IATI community might implement them.
label: BODY

text: Finding 1: False-positive matches for the IATI COVID-19 guidance
label: HH2

text: Focus area: IATI guidance
label: BODY

text: The IATI secretariat acted with speed to create and publish the IATI COVID-19 Guidance, and IATI
label: BODY

text: publishers adopted it quickly, making IATI one of the first useful sources for COVID-19-related aid
label: BODY

text: funding.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data | Join our mailing list | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Page 6 of 17
label: BODY

text: In making extensive use of the guidance, however, we have found areas where it introduces
label: BODY

text: ambiguities and could potentially result in false-positive matches for COVID-19 funding. For example,
label: BODY

text: IATI activity XI-IATI-CWSEC-YNCWG1051 from the Commonwealth Secretariat is entitled “A Resilient
label: BODY

text: Blue Commonwealth: Blue Charter” and is not related to the COVID-19 pandemic; however, it does
label: BODY

text: include the following text in the project description:
label: BODY

text: “Note: The emergence of the Covid-19 pandemic has altered some of the implementation
label: BODY

text: plans described above (especially holding in-person Action Group meetings).”
label: BODY

text: Following the IATI COVID-19 guidance, this activity counts as a positive match because the string
label: BODY

text: ‘COVID-19’ appears in the project title or description.
label: BODY

text: In our work, we attempted to minimise these false matches by classifying any activity with ‘COVID-19’
label: BODY

text: appearing only in the project description (and no other matching indicator) as a ‘loose’ match. As of 28
label: BODY

text: September 2021, there were $22.0 billion in commitments and $12.8 billion in spending that met only
label: BODY

text: the loose criteria but not other, stricter criteria (differences of 20% and 18% respectively).
label: BODY

text: There were pragmatic reasons to keep the guidance flexible, including limited metadata available at
label: BODY

text: the transaction level (see Issue 2) and the inability of many publishers to alter their information
label: BODY

text: systems quickly to support anything but changes to project titles and descriptions.
label: BODY

text: Recommendations:
label: BODY

text: Do not use free text in titles or descriptions as a flag in future IATI crisis-specific guidance (or at
label: BODY

text: least, limit this to the transaction level).
label: BODY

text: Focus future guidance on unambiguous, dedicated metadata elements like tag and
label: BODY

text: humanitarian-profile.
label: BODY

text: Modify IATI publisher data systems to support more-unambiguous flagging of crises or themes
label: BODY

text: in the future.
label: BODY

text: Next steps:
label: BODY

text: Work with the IATI technical team and secretariat to develop templates and best practices for
label: BODY

text: future IATI crisis-/theme-publishing guidance.
label: BODY

text: Modify the IATI standard to allow tag and humanitarian-profile at the transaction level (will
label: BODY

text: need to start as an extension, as described in Issue 2).
label: BODY

text: Inform IATI publishers about changes they can make to their information systems now to
label: BODY

text: support crisis- or theme-specific publishing guidance in the future (since such changes can
label: BODY

text: take several years to implement).
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data | Join our mailing list | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Page 7 of 17
label: BODY

text: Finding 2: IATI publishers do not share their commitments consistently
label: HH2

text: Focus area: IATI guidance
label: BODY

text: One of the goals of our work was to show the difference between money committed by aid
label: BODY

text: organizations toward the global COVID-19 response, and money actually spent. Unfortunately, IATI
label: BODY

text: publishers are not consistent about publishing both commitment and disbursement/expenditure
label: BODY

text: transactions.
label: BODY

text: For example, we found that WHO published information about $1.2 billion in spending, but no
label: BODY

text: commitments at all. That leads to two issues:
label: BODY

text: There is a loss of aid transparency, because it is not possible to determine how fully or quickly
label: BODY

text: the WHO has met its initial commitments.
label: BODY

text: There is a decrease in the accuracy of aggregate numbers, because WHO’s spending (without
label: BODY

text: corresponding commitments) exaggerates the global progress towards meeting COVID-19
label: BODY

text: commitments by $1.2 billion.
label: BODY

text: WHO is not unique. We found the same issue with many other publishers, including the Australian
label: BODY

text: Government, World Bank Trust Funds, the British Red Cross, and Concern Worldwide.
label: BODY

text: Recommendations:
label: BODY

text: Whenever possible, IATI publishers should share outgoing commitments as well as spending,
label: BODY

text: even if they happen at the same time.
label: BODY

text: When total outgoing commitments for an activity differ from spending, that should reflect the
label: BODY

text: real-world situation, not simply a lack of reporting.
label: BODY

text: The IATI community should discuss whether it is best practice to publish outgoing
label: BODY

text: commitments for planned expenses (such as salaries and travel) as well as planned
label: BODY

text: disbursements to other organizations, since IATI publishers often fail to distinguish the two
label: BODY

text: properly.
label: BODY

text: Next steps:
label: BODY

text: Update existing IATI guidance and training materials to emphasise the importance of
label: BODY

text: publishing outgoing commitment transactions to support aid transparency, including use
label: BODY

text: cases for data users.
label: BODY

text: Advocate for IATI report cards and dashboards to include publishing outgoing commitments as
label: BODY

text: a quality metric.
label: BODY

text: Propose an IATI extension or change to the standard to add a ‘no commitment’ flag to
label: BODY

text: transactions to identify legitimate exceptions.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data | Join our mailing list | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Page 8 of 17
label: BODY

text: Draw attention to IATI publishers who already follow best practices with commitments as
label: BODY

text: models for the rest of the IATI community.
label: BODY

text: Finding 3: Splitting IATI transactions by sector and recipient country/region
label: HH2

text: Focus area: IATI guidance
label: BODY

text: An IATI activity may target multiple sectors and/or recipient regions or countries, and it is often difficult
label: BODY

text: to allocate commitments or spending accurately across those different entities. For example, IATI
label: BODY

text: activity CA-3-P009467001 published by Global Affairs Canada (GAC) reports funding for agricultural
label: BODY

text: interventions in response to COVID-19. The programme targets eight regions and five sectors, with a
label: BODY

text: percentage value assigned to each.3
label: BODY

text: When GAC reported an outgoing commitment transaction of CA $6,000,000 to the International Fund
label: BODY

text: for Agricultural Development (IFAD), dividing the commitment by sector and region at the same time
label: BODY

text: produces totals that are overly specific and unlikely to be accurate, for example $48,000 committed to
label: BODY

text: Agricultural policy and administrative management in the Middle East (10% of 8% of $6 million).
label: BODY

text: In this case, GAC reported only one commitment and one spending transaction for the activity, but in
label: BODY

text: many cases, IATI publishers provide default splits at the activity level when there are multiple
label: BODY

text: transactions of each type, further adding to the allocation difficulties. For example, if GAC had made
label: BODY

text: commitments to 3 different aid organizations, it would have been unlikely that 0.8% of each
label: BODY

text: commitment would apply to Agricultural policy and administrative management in the Middle East.
label: BODY

text: Recommendations:
label: BODY

text: If feasible, large IATI publishers (like government donors) should break programmes down into
label: BODY

text: smaller, more geographically-targeted units by region or country, to improve aid transparency
label: BODY

text: in general. Doing so would also improve the ability of donors to meet their Grand Bargain
label: BODY

text: localisation commitments, by having programmes that a single local or national actor could
label: BODY

text: apply to implement.
label: BODY

text: When an activity contains more than one transaction of the same type, IATI publishers should
label: BODY

text: include sector and recipient country/region information at the transaction level rather than
label: BODY

text: the activity level, to make it easier to determine how much money is going to specific sectors
label: BODY

text: or geographical areas.
label: BODY

text: 3 The regions are South of Sahara (70%); South & Central Asia (9%); Middle East (8%); Far East Asia (5%); North &
label: BODY

text: Central America (2.5%); Oceania (2.5%); West Indies (2%), and South America (1%). The sectors are Agricultural
label: BODY

text: inputs (25%); Agricultural services (25%); Agricultural financial services (25%); Agricultural development (15%);
label: BODY

text: and Agricultural policy and administrative management (10%).
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data | Join our mailing list | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Page 9 of 17
label: BODY

text: Next steps:
label: BODY

text: Through the IATI Data Use Working Group, publish and circulate a guidance document on
label: BODY

text: processing IATI transactions by sector and recipient country/region to establish common best
label: BODY

text: practices, then propose that the IATI secretariat adopt it as official IATI guidance.
label: BODY

text: Advocate for IATI report cards and dashboards to add transaction-level metadata about
label: BODY

text: sectors and recipient countries/regions as a data-quality metric.
label: BODY

text: Recruit two major publishers as peer advocates to model best practices and two major data
label: BODY

text: users as advocates to demonstrate need.
label: BODY

text: Finding 4: Lack of information about transaction counterparties
label: HH2

text: Focus area: IATI guidance
label: BODY

text: With the exception of expenses, the IATI transaction types we considered all involve a counterparty (a
label: BODY

text: provider organization for incoming commitments or funding, and a receiver organization for outgoing
label: BODY

text: commitments or disbursements). IATI allows specifying each counterparty in up to three ways:
label: BODY

text: by name (e.g. “UNHCR”);
label: BODY

text: by organization identifier (e.g. “XM-DAC-41121”); and/or
label: BODY

text: by organization type (e.g. “40” for Multilateral).
label: BODY

text: Including this information in transactions4 is critical for aid transparency, and particularly for
label: BODY

text: traceability — the ability to track aid funding from its source to an actual aid activity in the field.
label: BODY

text: In the Spending Flows tab of our dashboard, we were able to show the counterparties as named by
label: BODY

text: each individual organization, but in most cases, we were unable to connect them, and could not
label: BODY

text: reliably include information about an organization provided by third parties. IATI publishers rarely use
label: BODY

text: organization identifiers in transactions (there are often none available for them to use), don’t specify
label: BODY

text: the organization type, and use wildly inconsistent naming conventions.
label: BODY

text: For example, in a recent selection of IATI activities targeting Somalia, all of the following spelling
label: BODY

text: variants appear for the same organization: “UNHCR”, "UNHCR/United Nations High Commissioner for
label: BODY

text: Refugees", "UNITED NATIONS HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR REFUGEES", "UNO Flüchtlingshilfe", "United
label: BODY

text: Nations High Commissioner for Refugees", "United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
label: BODY

text: (UNHCR)", and "United Nations Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees".
label: BODY

text: Even that inconsistency is better than the other common case, where IATI publishers do not name their
label: BODY

text: counterparties at all, especially when they are local or national organizations.
label: BODY

text: 4 IATI also allows using defaults from the participating organizations specified at the activity level when a
label: BODY

text: transaction does not specify a provider or receiver organization.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data | Join our mailing list | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Page 10 of 17
label: BODY

text: Recommendations:
label: BODY

text: Include the provider or receiver organizations (as appropriate) for each applicable transaction,
label: BODY

text: except where there is a serious security concern or other sensitivity.
label: BODY

text: List all participating organizations, including upstream funding organizations and downstream
label: BODY

text: implementing partners, for each activity, except where there is a serious security concern or
label: BODY

text: other sensitivity.
label: BODY

text: Name organizations as completely as possible (e.g. “Kenya Ministry of Health”, not just “MoH”).
label: BODY

text: Use organization identifiers whenever available.
label: BODY

text: Always include the organization type from the IATI Organization Type Codelist (e.g. code 24 for
label: BODY

text: a local or national NGO), even when the organization name and identifier are redacted for
label: BODY

text: security reasons.
label: BODY

text: Next steps:
label: BODY

text: Work with the IATI secretariat to update traceability guidance to emphasise the importance of
label: BODY

text: including information about transaction counterparties, and when/how to redact information
label: BODY

text: when necessary.
label: BODY

text: Improve the infrastructure for discovering organization identifiers and for creating or
label: BODY

text: requesting new identifiers for those organizations that do not already have one.
label: BODY

text: Leverage the Grand Bargain Localisation Workstream as an incentive for IATI publishers to
label: BODY

text: name partners more consistently (it is impossible to track localisation progress with IATI
label: BODY

text: unless publishers share their partners).
label: BODY

text: Identify IATI publishers who are already following best practices for traceability (e.g. Oxfam
label: BODY

text: Novib, Cordaid) and share them as models for other publishers to follow.
label: BODY

text: Finding 5: Limited metadata at the IATI transaction level
label: HH2

text: Focus area: IATI standard
label: BODY

text: The IATI standard allows extensive metadata at the activity level — serving as a default for all
label: BODY

text: transactions — but it allows much less metadata for individual transactions within an activity. For
label: BODY

text: example, there is no way to associate a specific transaction with a global humanitarian crisis, a
label: BODY

text: humanitarian response plan, or even a free-form IATI subject tag.
label: BODY

text: Since all of those were part of the IATI COVID-19 guidance, the result was that publishers did not have a
label: BODY

text: convenient way to associate a single transaction within a large activity with the global COVID-19
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Page 11 of 17
label: BODY

text: response, other than by using ‘COVID-19’ in the transaction description text,5 and there was likely
label: BODY

text: significant overcounting of COVID-19 funding when only a small part of the spending in a large activity
label: BODY

text: applied to the crisis.
label: BODY

text: Examples of other metadata that could be useful at the transaction level includes the original currency
label: BODY

text: and exchange rate, and direct relationships with transactions in other activities.
label: BODY

text: Recommendations:
label: BODY

text: Allow the inclusion of more metadata at the IATI transaction level, including tags and
label: BODY

text: humanitarian profiles.
label: BODY

text: Next steps:
label: BODY

text: Since IATI standard development is slow, begin by developing, documenting, and propagating
label: BODY

text: an IATI extension6 that adds a collection of useful metadata at the transaction level.
label: BODY

text: Create an IATI extension registry to raise visibility and avoid duplicate work.
label: BODY

text: Recruit two major IATI publishers to use the extension, to add credibility.
label: BODY

text: Advocate for two key IATI data users (such as d-portal) to take advantage of the extension, to
label: BODY

text: demonstrate its value.
label: BODY

text: Once the extension is in use, present it as evidence to advocate for an official change to the
label: BODY

text: IATI standard to support better transaction-level metadata.
label: BODY

text: 4. Conclusion
label: H1

text: The unprecedented scale of the COVID-19 pandemic shows why a global, multi-stakeholder data
label: BODY

text: standard is needed. Our work to create the dashboard and data story about COVID-19 funding would
label: BODY

text: not have been possible without the IATI standard and the hard work of its publishers. The Centre looks
label: BODY

text: forward to collaborating with the IATI community to make improvements to the standard and related
label: BODY

text: guidance so that valuable insights about aid activities are easier to generate and enable quicker
label: BODY

text: decisions.
label: BODY

text: We are especially grateful to the many stakeholders who provided input and feedback over the course
label: BODY

text: of this project. We would also like to acknowledge the guidance and support we received from the
label: BODY

text: United States Agency for International Development.
label: BODY

text: 6 An IATI extension is a collection of additional markup that publishers can add to their IATI reports, using an XML
label: BODY

text: Namespace to distinguish it from the primary IATI markup to avoid conflict or incompatibilities.
label: BODY

text: 5 Or later in the pandemic, via the use of a dubious OECD-DAC sector code for a COVID-19 pseudo-sector, which
label: BODY

text: further confuses the sector breakdowns described in Finding #1.
label: BODY

text: Annex A: IATI Transaction Types
label: H1

text: The IATI transaction types that we were interested in for this project were incoming commitments
label: BODY

text: (promises to pay money into an activity), incoming funding (actuals transfers of money into an
label: BODY

text: activity), outgoing commitments (promises to pay money out of an activity), disbursements (actual
label: BODY

text: transfers of money out an activity), and expenses (operating costs paid directly by the activity).
label: BODY

text: Typically, transactions come from or go to a different aid organization than the one reporting the
label: BODY

text: activity, but that is not always the case.
label: BODY

text: Because IATI publishers do not consistently distinguish between disbursements and expenses, we
label: BODY

text: combine them in the dashboard and data story into a single pseudo-transaction type “spending.”
label: BODY

text: Each activity contains zero or more transactions. Many types of metadata, such as the target sectors or
label: BODY

text: recipient countries, may appear at either the activity or the transaction level.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data | Join our mailing list | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Page 13 of 17
label: BODY

text: Annex B: Methodology Highlights
label: HH1

text: This section describes the algorithms and general methodology we used to process IATI data to
label: BODY

text: produce aggregate figures, and will be of interest primarily to software developers,
label: BODY

text: information-management specialists, and financial professionals.
label: BODY

text: The Centre shares all of the source code for this dashboard as open source software. Data is extracted
label: BODY

text: from d-portal.org and transformed every 24 hours.
label: BODY

text: For more information, view our public GitHub repositories:
label: BODY

text: Data processing scripts
label: BODY

text: Prepared data (automatically updated every 24 hours)
label: BODY

text: Activities and transactions — transactions.csv | transactions.json
label: BODY

text: Financial flows — flows.csv | flows.json
label: BODY

text: Data visualization front end
label: BODY

text: Data story source code
label: BODY

text: This section contains highlights only. For a full description of our processing methodology, see the
label: BODY

text: dashboard’s About page):
label: BODY

text: Data preparation: We run GitHub actions daily to extract IATI data from the D-Portal service,
label: BODY

text: transform it into CSV- and JSON-formatted reports, and then store it in GitHub Pages,
label: BODY

text: accessible over the Web.
label: BODY

text: Date limit: We include only outgoing financial transactions (types 3 or 4) dated after
label: BODY

text: 2020-01-01, to ensure relevance to the pandemic.
label: BODY

text: Currency: Unless they are already denominated in US dollars (USD), the dashboard converts
label: BODY

text: all transaction values to USD before performing any other operations.
label: BODY

text: Relevance: We follow the IATI COVID-19 Guidance for IATI Publishers and later additions to the
label: BODY

text: OECD-DAC sector codes, and flag all matches as strictly-relevant, with the following
label: BODY

text: exceptions:
label: BODY

text: If the string “COVID-19” appears only in the activity description, and the activity or
label: BODY

text: transaction meets none of the other IATI guidance, we flag it only as loosely-relevant.
label: BODY

text: If the string “COVID” or “CORONAVIRUS” appears in the activity title or in the activity or
label: BODY

text: transaction description, we also flag it as loosely relevant.
label: BODY

text: Spending: The dashboard does not make a distinction between disbursement and expense
label: BODY

text: transactions (types 3 or 4 in the IATI Transaction Type Codelist), but treat both as “spending”
label: BODY

text: for the sake of this dashboard.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data | Join our mailing list | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Page 14 of 17
label: BODY

text: Sector simplification: We have simplified the sectors, rolling them up to the top-level
label: BODY

text: OECD-DAC sector groups, to make the aggregated totals more usable.
label: BODY

text: Allocation to sectors and recipient countries: If an activity lists multiple sectors and/or
label: BODY

text: recipient countries, the dashboard divides each transaction by the percentages given for both.
label: BODY

text: The sectors and recipient countries for the transaction are used if provided at the transaction
label: BODY

text: level, and otherwise the dashboard defaults to those used at the activity level.
label: BODY

text: Deduplication: we subtract the larger of incoming commitments or incoming spending from
label: BODY

text: outgoing commitments and from outgoing spending to determine the net new commitments
label: BODY

text: and net new spending that an activity contributes to a sector, recipient country, or the overall
label: BODY

text: response. We do not perform deduplication when showing results only for a single
label: BODY

text: organization.
label: BODY

text: Internal transactions: in the flows tab, we exclude internal transactions (where the provider
label: BODY

text: and receiver organization are the same) whenever we are able to detect them.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data | Join our mailing list | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Page 15 of 17
label: BODY

text: Annex C: Stakeholder Consultations
label: H1

text: The Centre conducted two rounds of stakeholder consultations, one before and one after the technical
label: BODY

text: implementation of the IATI COVID-19 Funding Dashboard.
label: BODY

text: The first round of consultations, in late 2020, involved interviews with seven IATI stakeholders.7 The
label: HH3

text: main focus was on the earlier version of the dashboard and the extent to which it met the
label: BODY

text: organizations’ needs. From those discussions, the following key points emerged:
label: BODY

text: A tool like this was important for donors and other aid organizations to understand the wider
label: BODY

text: context of the COVID-19 financial response and the quality/usefulness of IATI data sharing.
label: BODY

text: Key headline figures (like the total funding to date) are valuable.
label: BODY

text: Users are most interested in looking at their own data first.
label: BODY

text: The presentation of financial flows between organizations was valuable.
label: BODY

text: IATI-specific terminology alienated many users.
label: BODY

text: Users were disappointed at the lack of time-series data (in the context of an ongoing
label: BODY

text: pandemic).
label: BODY

text: There was little user retention: once users visited the dashboard once, they were unlikely to
label: BODY

text: return.
label: BODY

text: In response to these findings, we made several changes to the dashboard:
label: BODY

text: We used only information from IATI publishers, so that all the data came from the same
label: BODY

text: ecosystem, and we would be able to “hold up a mirror” to IATI data.
label: BODY

text: We simplified options for filtering and displaying data, and added pop-up help.
label: BODY

text: We removed most of the IATI-specific terminology and replaced it with
label: BODY

text: more-broadly-accessible language.
label: BODY

text: We simplified pages to reduce the need for scrolling.
label: BODY

text: We preserved the ability of the original dashboard to bookmark specific data views, so that
label: BODY

text: (for example) a user could bookmark their own data and come back to it later to see how it had
label: BODY

text: changed.
label: BODY

text: 7 The stakeholders interviewed in the first round were Development Initiatives (DI), the Directorate-General for
label: BODY

text: European Civil Protection and Aid Operations (DG-ECHO), the International Rescue Committee (IRC), the
label: BODY

text: Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs (NL-MFA), the United States Agency for International Development
label: BODY

text: (USAID), the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR), and the World Health Organization (WHO).
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data | Join our mailing list | Twitter: @humdata | Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Page 16 of 17
label: BODY

text: The second round of consultations, in the second quarter of 2021, involved five IATI stakeholders,
label: HH2

text: some of whom were also in the first round.8 The main focus areas were demonstrating the updated
label: BODY

text: version of the dashboard, soliciting feedback, and providing recommendations for each organization’s
label: BODY

text: own IATI publishing based on our findings. The following key points emerged from the second round:
label: BODY

text: Stakeholders considered the dashboard useful, and could see ways to integrate it into their
label: BODY

text: own planning and operations:
label: BODY

text: “Eye opening, now I can go back and ask for extra capacity to make it so we can actually
label: BODY

text: publish transactions.”
label: BODY

text: “Our direct expenditure is remarkably large. That goes contrary to everything about local
label: BODY

text: humanitarian leadership.”
label: BODY

text: Simplifying the content (reduced scrolling) and using only IATI data significantly improved
label: BODY

text: usability.
label: BODY

text: Some users were able to find errors in their own IATI reporting quickly, in a way that they had
label: BODY

text: not easily been able to do before.
label: BODY

text: The new timeline chart was popular.
label: BODY

text: The “quick filters” shortcuts that we added to help users get quick results were little used.
label: BODY

text: The summary “doughnut charts” that we introduced caused confusion.
label: BODY

text: While significantly simpler, the logic of results filtering was still not clear to all users.9
label: BODY

text: Desire to see commitments as well as spending on the flows tab.
label: BODY

text: It was not possible to do a further major redesign after the second round of consultations, but we did
label: BODY

text: make some improvements and recorded the feedback (positive and negative) to help us improve the
label: BODY

text: usability of future dashboards, including possible later versions of this one for other crises and
label: BODY

text: themes.
label: BODY

text: 9 It is possible that presenting users with a set of filters is never a good user experience for people who are not
label: BODY

text: information-management specialists, no matter how a site presents them. This area deserves more
label: BODY

text: user-experience research.
label: BODY

text: 8 The stakeholders interviewed in the second round were the Danish Refugee Council (DRC), NL-MFA, Oxfam
label: BODY

text: Novib, UNHCR, and WHO.
label: BODY
